planets.description: Mercury, the smallest and closest planet to the Sun, is a rocky world with extreme temperature variations. Its surface is covered in craters and has little to no atmosphere, making it inhospitable for life.

Venus, the second planet from the Sun, is a hot and hostile world with a thick atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide. It experiences a runaway greenhouse effect, making it the hottest planet in our solar system.

Earth, the third planet from the Sun, is the only known celestial body to support life. It has a diverse environment with oceans, continents, and a variety of ecosystems. Earth is characterized by its dynamic climate and abundant water.

Mars, often called the 'Red Planet' due to its iron-rich soil, is the fourth planet from the Sun. It has a thin atmosphere and is home to the tallest volcano and the deepest canyon in our solar system. Scientists are intrigued by the possibility of past microbial life on Mars.

Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system, is a gas giant with a strong magnetic field. It has a prominent system of colorful bands and a large storm known as the Great Red Spot. Jupiter's numerous moons include the four largest, known as the Galilean moons.

Saturn, famous for its stunning ring system, is a gas giant with a diverse collection of moons. The rings are made up of icy particles and dust, creating a breathtaking celestial display. Saturn is the second-largest planet in our solar system.

Uranus, a gas giant lying on its side, is the seventh planet from the Sun. It has a unique rotation axis, and its atmosphere contains methane, giving the planet a blue-green hue. Uranus has a system of rings, though they are much fainter than Saturn's.

Neptune, the eighth and farthest known planet from the Sun, is a gas giant with a deep blue color. It has powerful winds and a dynamic atmosphere, featuring dark storms and a notable dark spot. Neptune has a system of rings and a diverse family of moons.

sun.description: The Sun is a blazing, star-sized sphere of hot, ionized gases at the center of our solar system. Composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, it produces light and heat through nuclear fusion. Its gravity keeps planets in orbit, and its energy sustains life on Earth. The Sun is about 4.6 billion years old and will likely shine for billions more years.
